docs.title: Tonatiuh Matos
docs.text:
He completed his undergraduate degree in physics and mathematics and subsequently his master's degree in physics at the Escuela Superior de Física y Matemáticas of the Instituto Politécnico Nacional (IPN). He obtained his doctorate in Theoretical Physics in 1987 from Friedrich Schiller University of Jena, Germany, and his habilitation in Astrophysics in 1998 from the same university.

He completed postdoctoral fellowships at the University of Vienna and the Vienna University of Technology. He has conducted research at the Albert Einstein Institute of the Max Planck Foundation in Germany and at German and American universities. He has been a visiting professor at the University of British Columbia in Vancouver, Canada.

He was Founding Vice President of the División de Gravitación y Física Matemática of the Sociedad Mexicana de Física (SMF) in 1992 and subsequently President in 1995. He has also been a founder and co-organizer of the Escuela Mexicana de Astrofísica (EMA) since 1998 and Founding Secretary General of the Instituto Avanzado de Cosmología (IAC) from 2007 to 2015. He served as President of the SMF from 2019 to 2021.

He has published over 250 articles, 150 of which are in indexed journals of Mathematical and Theoretical Physics, with over 4,700 citations. Several of these have been included in the Featured Articles list of the journal Classical and Quantum Gravity or have been cited extensively. Six are book chapters, over 50 are conference proceedings, and more than a dozen appear in popular science journals.

He published: The popular science books: ¿De qué está hecho el Universo? and, in 2025, Agujeros de Gusano y Propulsión por Curvatura, co-authored with Miguel Alcubierre, both from the "La ciencia para todos" series of the Fondo de Cultura Económica (Economic Culture Fund);

the novel El Tesoro de Motecuhzoma Xocoyotzin with Editorial Colofón;

the popular science book Radiación Cósmica de Fondo del Universo with Editorial Colofón;

the monograph Principios Matemáticos para Ciencias Exactas with Editorial IAC, also published by Colofón;

and the videos: ¿De qué está hecho el Universo?, with over 10,000 views,

and The Scientific Version of Genesis, with over 5,500 views, both on YouTube.

He has edited seven specialized books and participated in the organization of 46 conferences on gravitation, cosmology, and astrophysics in Mexico and abroad.

He has graduated 22 doctoral students, two of whom received the Arturo Rosenblueth Prize from Cinvestav and another the Weizmann Prize from the Academia Mexicana de Ciencias (AMC), both for best doctoral dissertation. In addition, two of them have been awarded the Marcos Moshinsky Chair at the Instituto de Física of the Universidad Nacional Autónoma de México (UNAM).

He has also supervised 42 master's theses and 10 undergraduate theses, several of which have also received awards.

These students, in turn, have supervised numerous undergraduate and master's theses, and more than 40 doctoral dissertations; two of these also received the Weizmann Prize.

Currently, virtually all of his graduates are members of the Sistema Nacional de Investigadores (SNI), four of them at Level III. He has supervised 20 postdoctoral researchers. He has participated as a speaker at more than 150 conferences and has been invited as a speaker to more than 60 international conferences.

He has founded three research groups. In 2001, together with Miguel Alcubierre and Darío Núñez of the ICN (Instituto de Ciencias Nucleares), he founded the Astrophysical Supercomputing Laboratory (LaSumA) at Cinvestav (Centro de Investigación y de Estudios Avanzados), a cluster of 64 processors for high-level work in numerical relativity, the first of its kind in Latin America.

He has taught dozens of undergraduate, master's, and doctoral courses at Mexican, German, Austrian, and Canadian universities.

He has been a member of the SMF since 1982, the AMC since 1992, the SNI (Level III) since 2003, Sigma Xi, Scientific Research Society since 2004, the New York Academy of Sciences since 2007 (by invitation), and the American Physical Society since 2013.

He was awarded the Scientific Research Prize of the Mexican Physics Society in 2007 and the Marcos Moshinsky Medal from the Instituto de Física of the UNAM in 2022.

He has served on: the AMC Admissions Committee (2006-2010), the Evaluation Committee of the Instituto de Matemáticas of UNAM (2008-2014), the PRIDE Committee of the Instituto de Astronomia of UNAM (2010-2014), the Evaluation Committee of the SNI 2010-2012 (elected), the PRIDE Special Committee for the area of ​​Physics and Mathematics 2014-2016 (awarded by the Rector of UNAM), the AMC Awards Committee 2014-2016 (elected), the SNI Appeals Committee 2015, of the CONACYT Research Chair Evaluation Committee 2017 and 2020, of the Marcos Moshinsky Research Chair Awards Committee 2021, of the Evaluation Committee of the Institute of Nuclear Sciences at UNAM 2017-2022.

His work now focuses on discovering the nature of dark matter and dark energy, which represent more than 96% of the matter in the universe. In 1998, he proposed that dark matter could be a spinless particle with an ultralight mass, and initiated the first systematic study of this paradigm in the world. This model is now one of the most popular and favored models for the nature of dark matter, which makes up 25% of the matter in the universe. See, for example, “On the hypothesis that cosmological dark matter is composed of ultra-light bosons,” by Lam Hui, Jeremiah P. Ostriker, Scott Tremaine, and Edward Witten, Physical Review D95, 043541 (2017). arXiv:1610.08297.

docs.title: Compton Mass Dark Energy (CMaDE)
docs.text:
Recent cosmological observations, such as those from DESI, suggest that dark energy may not be fully described by a cosmological constant but could instead behave as a dynamical component evolving with cosmic time. In previous work, we examined the possibility that long-wavelength gravitational perturbations on scales comparable to the apparent comoving horizon \(\eta\) generate an effective geometric correction to the Einstein equations. This leads to a global term scaling as \(1 / \eta^2\) that behaves locally as an effective cosmological constant, interpretable as an emergent gravitational Compton-mass scale relevant only at cosmological distances. We refer to this scenario as the Compton Mass Dark Energy (CMaDe) model. We confronted CMaDE with low-redshift datasets-DESI DR2, Pantheon + (without SHOES), Cosmic Chronometer \(H(z)\) measurements, and CMB distance priors-using a Markov Chain Monte Carlo analysis, comparing its performance with \(\Lambda \mathrm{CDM}\). Considering both Cold Dark Matter (CDM) and Scalar-Field Dark Matter (SFDM), we find the same direction of energy transfer into the CMaDE term, with fits slightly better than \(\Lambda \mathrm{CDM}\). Assuming \(\Lambda \mathrm{CDM}\)-like behavior at high redshift, these results suggest a sightly improvement in favor to the CMaDE model.

docs.title: Scalar Field Dark Matter (SFDM)
docs.text:
The Scalar Field Dark Matter model has been known in various ways throughout its history; Fuzzy, BEC, Wave, Ultralight, Axion-like Dark Matter, etc. All of them consist in proposing that dark matter of the universe is a spinless field Φ that follows the Klein-Gordon (KG) equation of motion □Φ − dV/dΦ = 0, for a given scalar field potential V. The difference between different models is sometimes the choice of the scalar field potential V. In the literature we find that people usually work in the non-relativistic, weak-field limit of the Klein-Gordon equation, where it transforms into the Schrödinger equation and the Einstein equations into the Poisson equation, reducing the KG-Einstein system, to the Schrödinger-Poisson system. Here we review some of the most interesting achievements of this model from the historical point of view and its comparison with observations, showing that this model could be the last answer to the question about the nature of dark matter in the universe.

In 1998, it was proposed in (Matos and Guzman, 2000) that SF can solve the problem of dark matter and that this field can explain the rotation curves of galaxies, initiating the first systematic study of this paradigm. Subsequently, the idea of SFDM has been rediscovered many times, such as Fuzzy DM (Hu et al., 2000), Quintessential DM (Arb et al., 2001; Arbey et al., 2002); Ultralight DM (Amendola and Barbieri, 2006; Lundgren et al., 2010); Bose-Einstein condensate DM (Boehmer and Harko, 2007; Rindler-Daller and Shapiro, 2010; Chavanis, 2011); Wave DM ((Bray, 2010; Schive et al., 2014)); Super Fluid DM (Berezhiani et al., 2023a), etc. In 2017 this idea became fashionable and one of the favorite candidates to explain DM after the publication of the article (Hui et al., 2017).

The SFDM model has two parameters, the mass m=̂mc/ℏ, where ̂m is the mass in grams, and the self-interaction parameter λ. With these two parameters, it is possible to fit a large number of DM observations into the universe. The objective of this work is to historically list some of its most important achievements, and we will focus on the following.

• Good agreement of the rotation curves of stars and dust around galaxies.

• Good agreement with cosmological constrains and Big Bang Nucleosynthesis

• An alternative solution to the cusp-core problem.

• An alternative solution to the problem of satellites.

• The central black holes in galaxies.

• This is in excellent agreement with the CMB and MPS cosmological observations.

• The agreement with the cosmological numerical simulation.

• A natural explanation of the anomalous trajectories of satellites around galaxies.

Some predictions.

• The existence of a soliton at the center of galaxies.

• The structure formation of galaxies according to cosmological numerical simulations

• An alternative explanation to the Fermi Bubbles

See: Short review of the main achievements of the scalar field, fuzzy, ultralight, wave, BEC dark matter model. Tonatiuh Matos, Luis Ureña-López and Jae-Weon Lee. Frontiers in Astronomy and Space Sciences, 12 February 2024

docs.title: Stochastic Quantum Mechanics (SQM)
docs.text:
It is a fact that spacetime is stochastic, possibly due to its quantum fluctuations or the existence of a gravitational wave background. Based on this, we discard stochasticity in Einstein's equations, since these fluctuations curve spacetime but alter its gravitation very little, but we do consider the trajectories of particles in this stochastic spacetime. In this paradigm, particles move along the geodesic plus a stochastic term. In this project we propose a new paradigm for Quantum Mechanics based on this fact.

It is a fact that we live within a Gravitational Wave Background (GWB). Strictly speaking, all motion that occurs in the universe generates gravitational waves. From the Big Bang, inflation, the production of primordial black holes, the formation of black holes, collisions between them, the movement of galaxies through the universe, etc. These fluctuations in spacetime are quite small, but if Planck's formula for the energy of massless particles holds true: \(E=h\nu=hc/\lambda\), where \(h\) is Planck's constant and \(\lambda\) is the wavelength of the particle, these fluctuations contain a large amount of energy, even when they are sufficiently small (where \(\lambda\) is small). Therefore, it is worthwhile to take this fluctuation in spacetime into account. This idea is similar to that of a lake where boats do not perceive the small fluctuations, but ants or fleas do perceive the movement of the waves.

There are several ways to consider the gravitational wave background. Of course, we could treat the GWB as a stochastic spacetime and perform all the complex mathematical calculations (see for example Isaac Layton and Jonathan Oppenheim - PRX Quantum 5 (2024) 2, 020331). Instead, let's assume that the GWB minimally alters the gravitation of spacetime, so that we can neglect stochasticity in Einstein's field equation and consider it only for geodesics. In E. Escobar-Aguilar, Tonatiuh Matos and J.I. Jimenez-Aquino, Fundamental Klein-Gordon Equation from Stochastic Mechanics in Curved Spacetime, -Found.Phys. 55 (2025) 4, 60 we did this and showed that, if we consider the geodesic of a particle plus a stochastic term in an arbitrary curved spacetime, the field equation of the particle is the Klein-Gordon equation for the complex function \(\Phi=\sqrt{n}\exp(\Theta)\). We showed that the angle \(\Theta\) determines the geodesic of the particles in spacetime and \(n\) determines their stochastic velocity. Since the non-relativistic limit of the Klein-Gordon equation is the Schrödinger equation, we conclude that quantum mechanics (QM) can be determined from the stochastic nature of spacetime fluctuations, rather than from the uncertainty principle. In this way, we obtain a completely new interpretation of QM.

In the present project we use this fact and study the behavior of photons close to the horizon of a black hole. We find exact solutions of the Klein-Gordon equation and with theise solutions we can determine the geodesic and the stochastic velocity of the photon. We can plot the trajectories of photons near to a black hole and see them in different frames.

docs.title: Wormholes (WH) and Black Holes (BH)
docs.text:
To date, many exotic predictions of Einstein's equations have been corroborated, with one exception: wormholes (WHs). In the last time, we have analysed new exact solutions to the Einstein-Maxwell-Dilaton or Phantom equations, which represent rotating WHs with magnetic and electric fields. The solutions contain a ring singularity that, like other solutions, satisfies Wormhole Cosmic Censorship; that is, the singularity is causally disconnected by the WH throat. We have shown that this WH are traversable through regions close to the poles, where the tidal forces and magnetic field are reasonably small. We satisfy the energy conditions for the dilaton-like solution. We argue that if dilaton-like interactions can exist in nature, for example, if extra dimensions exist as in superstring theory, WHs are a natural realistic prediction of Einstein's equations, and we should be able to observe them somehow, probably as black hole mimics. We have presented several examples of realistic WH that may occur in nature, and we also introduce new exact black hole solutions.

Since Einstein's equations (EEq) were formulated in 1916, their predictions have been stunning. Einstein himself predicted that his equations implied the existence of gravitational fluctuations, gravitational waves, but these are so small that, according to him, they are impossible to see or detect. Today, we have detected them hundreds of times, giving rise to a new era of astronomy where we detect astrophysical objects using gravitational waves instead of photons. In the same year, Karl Schwarzschild found the first exact, spherically symmetric solution to EEq. Later, it was discovered that Schwarzschild's solution implies the existence of small, compact objects where light cannot escape. Therefore, these objects were called black holes. At that time it was believed that the existence of these objects was impossible and that there must be a mechanism to prevent their existence. Today, we have at least two photographs of these objects and hundreds of detections of collisions of these objects using gravitational waves. One of the most interesting predictions of the EEq is the expansion of the universe. Even Einstein refused to accept it. He famously added the cosmological constant to his equations to prevent expansion, but without success. Today, we not only know that the universe is expanding, but that it is accelerating, something Einstein's equations cannot predict. And so on. To date, we are unaware of any important physical predictions of Einstein's equations that cannot be observed or detected, with the exception of wormholes (WH). The high level of prediction of the EEq is astonishing, and many of them are surprising.

In this proyect, we use the Einstein-Maxwell-Dilaton (EMD) theory to derive a new solutions that generalises wormhole solutions: the asymptotically flat configuration and the NUT spacetime incorporating a magnetic monopole and a scalar field, thereby obtaining new exact solutions of the EEq which, in the framework, which includes electric and magnetic fields together with a scalar field that may be of dilaton type (i.e., real and coupled to the electromagnetic field) or of phantom type (i.e., featuring a negative kinetic term in the Lagrangian). This configurations are further separated into super-extreme and sub-extreme regime, which correspond, respectively, to a wormhole and to new exact black hole solutions (valid for any selected gravitational theory, coupled to a phantom/dilaton-type scalar field, and accommodating both asymptotically flat and NUT-type spacetime geometries).
